Alternatively, if he thinks the other player is also trying to maximize their own share, maybe he should give less because the other might retaliate by giving a higher amount in response.

But without knowing the other's strategy, it's hard to say. Maybe the Nash equilibrium here would be for both to give half of the $10 each? So N=5 and the other gives 5 as well, resulting in both getting back 15 each, so their net gain is 10 each.

Assuming only one decision: Jamal gives N dollars to the other, who returns 3N. He receives $10 initially.

So his net is 10 + (3N - N) =10 +2N.

To maximize this, he should give as much as possible without leaving himself with less than what he started with or perhaps to maximize 2N, so give the maximum allowed. But the problem doesn't specify a limit on how much he can give.

But in reality, if he gives all $10, then after transaction, he has nothing left but the other player takes it and returns $30, so his net is still $10. So maybe giving less to have some left would be better.

Alternatively, perhaps the maximum profit occurs when N=5, leading to a net gain of $10, making his total $20.

So after considering all this, I think Jamal should give $5.
